week1.practice1_html:
Toby, your shedding is still in waves because your main triggers—chronic illness + med changes + stress—are ongoing. Right now you’re in the peak/stabilization overlap: the worst fallout hit a few months after March–May, and your body hasn’t settled yet. The Big Domino here is locking your sleep rhythm. A steady clock tells your hormones and follicles: “no more emergencies.” This begins the shift from unstable waves toward stabilization so regrowth can start on time. 🌙

What to do

  • Choose a fixed bedtime and stick within 30 minutes, every day (yes, weekends).
  • Set a fixed wake time that feels realistic and repeatable.
  • Protect a ~8‑hour sleep window with nothing scheduled before bedtime.
  • If you wake once, keep lights low and return quickly—don’t reset devices/clocks.

Your recommended schedule

  • Bedtime target: 10:45–11:15 pm
  • Wake target: 6:45–7:15 am (even weekends)
  • Morning anchor: light exposure within 30 min of waking (step outside, 5 min)

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Pick which 11 pm bedtime feels most doable and commit—write it down.
  2. Set a gentle alarm for both bedtime reminder and morning wake.
  3. If stress thoughts keep you up, give yourself one “worry pad” time earlier in evening so your brain unloads before bed.
  4. Keep last meal ~1h before bed as you already do—this reduces reflux/discomfort wake-ups.
  5. If illness flares shift your day, aim to hold wake time constant; slide bedtime only if absolutely needed.

Why this works (for you)

  • Your ongoing high stress keeps cortisol spiky; a stable sleep rhythm flattens those spikes, lowering telogen push.
  • Irregular periods + thyroid history suggest hormones are sensitive; deep sleep boosts progesterone/thyroid tone that defend hair.
  • Because your med change ended in May, your worst shed window was Jul–Aug. This habit shortens the lag and pulls you faster into stabilization.
  • Limited protein + low iron risk means your follicles need every signal of “safety”; consistent circadian cues reassure them growth can restart soon.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Staying up >90 min past target more than twice/week → resets the cortisol surge; refocus on wake anchor first.
  • Green lights: Within 7–10 days you’ll notice easier morning energy, less afternoon crash, steadier shed counts.
  • Remember: you’re not failing if a flare disrupts one night. Each reset back to schedule is a victory. ❤️
week1.practice2_html:
```html

Toby, your shedding has come in waves and you’re still waiting for baby hairs. With high stress, ongoing thyroid/illness triggers, and irregular cycles, your body is stuck in the “onset/peak” window. A wind down ritual is the domino that calms night cortisol, steadies hormones, and helps you cross into stabilization sooner so regrowth can finally begin. 🌙

What to do

  • Power down screens 45–60 min before bed (blue‑light brakes stress hormones).
  • Pair a warm shower or bath with gentle stretching—link body with “sleep mode.”
  • Use a 5‑minute journal or breathing practice to park ruminating thoughts.
  • Finish your last meal at least 90 min before sleep to avoid night cortisol spikes.

Your recommended schedule

  • Fixed wake: 7:00 am daily (+/‑15 min).
  • Bedtime target: 11:00 pm (8‑hour window).
  • Morning light: 10 min outdoors within 30 min of waking to set your circadian anchor.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Set a “wind down alarm” at 9:45 pm to step away from intense tasks/screens.
  2. Take a 5‑min hot shower; as your body temperature drops afterward, sleep drive rises.
  3. Stretch or do 3 rounds of slow 4‑7‑8 breathing to calm high evening stress.
  4. Write a 3‑line “brain dump” to offload anxious thoughts before lights out.
  5. Place a water glass and gentle alarm by your bed so mornings feel low‑friction.

Why this works (for you)

  • Because your chronic illness is ongoing, a strong circadian anchor flattens night cortisol that otherwise keeps hairs in shedding (telogen).
  • Stress journaling reduces rumination → steadier progesterone/thyroid tone → lowers TE pressure.
  • Spacing food from bedtime avoids nighttime metabolic stress, supporting iron and protein use for regrowth.
  • Your triggers began Feb–Mar; shedding waves in Sept show lag. This protocol shortens the stabilization window so baby hairs can emerge closer to schedule.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Pushing bedtime past midnight or scrolling in bed → fragments sleep, delays stabilization. Reset with the 9:45 pm alarm.
  • Green lights: You notice quicker sleep onset, fewer 2 am thought spirals, waking more refreshed within 7–10 days.
  • And if a night slips? ❤️ Just return the next night—consistency over perfection builds your new baseline.
```
week1.practice3_html:
Toby, your shedding comes in waves and you haven’t seen baby hairs yet — which suggests you’re still in the stabilization window. With ongoing stress, thyroid illness, and irregular cycles, sleep is the one lever that steadies cortisol and sets the stage for regrowth. Deep, regular sleep is your “big domino”: when you move this, everything downstream (hormones, iron use, protein repair) lines up to help you cross from unstable shedding into early regrowth. 🌙

What to do

  • Anchor your wake time within the same 30 min window daily, even weekends.
  • Keep caffeine cutoff at or before 2 pm (you’re already close — lock it in).
  • Push last meal 2–3h before bed so digestion isn’t spiking cortisol at night.
  • Cool, dark, quiet bedroom → better melatonin quality.
  • Add a short daylight walk in the morning to reinforce circadian rhythm.

Your recommended schedule

  • Wake: 7:00 am (±15 min)
  • First light: get outside ~7:15–7:45 am
  • No caffeine after 2:00 pm
  • Evening wind-down: 9:30 pm (dim lights, screens low)
  • Sleep window: 10:30 pm – 6:45/7:00 am

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Decide on your fixed wake time and set alarms/reminders for both wake + wind-down.
  2. Move your last meal slightly earlier — aim for at least 2h before bed.
  3. When stress or rumination hit, use a notebook/phone “brain dump” before bed to clear loops.
  4. Morning: step outside to anchor circadian rhythm, even on cloudy days.
  5. Protect your room: keep it about 65–67°F, lights out, earplugs/eyemask if needed.
  6. Stick with it for at least 10 nights before judging; stability builds before regrowth shows. 🌱

Why this works (for you)

  • Because your stress is high and thyroid illness is ongoing, consistent deep sleep lowers night cortisol spikes that otherwise prolong telogen shedding.
  • Your loss began ~6 months ago, so stabilization is due now — better sleep shortens the lag, letting baby hairs emerge on schedule.
  • Earlier meals + circadian light cues keep progesterone/thyroid tone steadier, which buffers against irregular cycles and nutrient loss.
  • Improved melatonin signals boost growth-phase entry, meaning new hairs can appear once shedding plateaus.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: New meds that disturb sleep rhythms → tell your doctor; if you drift into <6h nights, reset with naps earlier in the day, not late evenings.
  • Green lights: Within 7–10 days, fewer 2–3 am wake-ups; within 2 weeks, more balanced energy in mornings and slightly less clump size on wash days.
  • Be gentle if you miss a night — consistency, not perfection, is what flips your hair cycle forward. ❤️
